pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:0.5: 8. The training rule on what is set aside
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.1: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.2: a certain man said to his wife,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.3: “I’m going to give robe-cloth to Venerable Upananda.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.4: An alms-collecting monk heard that man making that statement.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.5: He then went to Upananda the Sakyan and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.7: In such-and-such a place I heard a man tell his wife
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.8: that he’s going to give you robe-cloth.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.10: Upananda then went to that man and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.11: “Is it true that you want to give me robe-cloth?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.13: that’s just what I was thinking.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.14: “If that’s the case, give me such-and-such robe-cloth.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.15: For what’s the point of giving robe-cloth that I won’t use?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.16: That man complained and criticized him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.17: “These Sakyan monastics have great desires. They’re not content.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.18: It’s no easy matter to give them robe-cloth.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.19: How could Venerable Upananda come to me and say what kind of robe-cloth he wants without first being invited by me to do so?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.20: The monks heard the complaints of that man,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.21: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.22: “How could Venerable Upananda go to a householder and say what kind of robe-cloth he wants without first being invited to do so?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.23: After rebuking him in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned Upananda:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.24: “Is it true, Upananda, that you did this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.28: “Foolish man, people who are unrelated don’t know what’s appropriate and inappropriate, what’s good and bad, in dealing with each other.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.31: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.32.1: ‘If a male or female householder has set aside a robe fund for an unrelated monk, thinking,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.33: “With this robe fund I will buy robe-cloth and give it to monk so-and-so;”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.34: and if that monk, without first being invited, goes to them and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, saying,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.35: “Please use this robe fund to buy such-and-such robe-cloth and then give it to me,”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:1.1.36: and he does so because he wants something fine, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.2: for the benefit of a monk; making a monk the object of consideration, one wants to give to him.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.4: anyone who is not a descendant of one’s male ancestors going back eight generations, either on the mother’s side or on the father’s side.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.6: any man who lives at home.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.8: any woman who lives at home.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.10: money, gold, a pearl, a gem, a coral, a crystal, cloth, thread, or cotton wool.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.12: with that which is at one’s disposal.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.18: the monk the robe fund has been set aside for.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.20: he or she has not said beforehand: “Venerable, what kind of robe-cloth do you need? What kind of robe-cloth can I buy for you?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.22: having gone to their house or having gone wherever.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.23: Specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.24: please make it long or wide or closely woven or soft.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.26: that which is at one’s disposal.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.28: long or wide or closely woven or soft.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.34: wanting something good, wanting something expensive.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.35: If that lay person buys robe-cloth that is long, wide, closely woven, or soft because of the monk’s statement, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.36: When he gets the robe-cloth, it becomes subject to relinquishment.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.37: The robe-cloth should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.38: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.39: (To be expanded as in [Bu Np 1:3.2.5](pli-tv-bu-vb-np1:3.2.5)–Bu Np 1:3.2.29, with appropriate substitutions.)
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.40: ‘Venerables, this robe-cloth, which I received after going to an unrelated householder and saying what kind of robe-cloth I wanted without first being invited, is to be relinquished.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.41: I relinquish it to the Sangha.’ …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.1.44: ‘I give this robe-cloth back to you.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.2.1: If the householder is unrelated and the monk perceives them as such, and, without first being invited, he goes to them and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.2.2: If the householder is unrelated, but the monk is unsure of it, and, without first being invited, he goes to them and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.2.3: If the householder is unrelated, but the monk perceives them as related, and, without first being invited, he goes to them and specifies the kind of robe-cloth he wants, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.2.4: If the householder is related, but the monk perceives them as unrelated, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.2.5: If the householder is related, but the monk is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.2.6: If the householder is related and the monk perceives them as such, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.3.3: if it is from those who have given an invitation;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.3.4: if it is for the benefit of another;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.3.5: if it is by means of his own property;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.3.6: if the householder wishes to buy something expensive, but the monk has them buy something inexpensive;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.3.8: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np8:2.3.9: The training rule on what is set aside, the eighth, is finished.
